intro: Acantholimon laxiusculum, commonly known as the slender flaxvetch, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, pea-like flowers that range in color from white to pale purple, typically blooming in early spring. It thrives in dry, rocky soils and is often found in sagebrush steppe and grassland habitats. Acantholimon laxiusculum plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for small insects and wildlife.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acantholimon laxiusculum is primarily native to the western United States, particularly in California and Oregon. It thrives in coastal and inland areas with sandy or gravelly soils. This plant is commonly found in dunes, coastal bluffs, and open grasslands. It is well adapted to dry, sunny conditions and can tolerate salt spray. Acantholimon laxiusculum is an important part of the local flora in these regions.

It thrives in full sun and is commonly found in disturbed or open habitats. This plant is typically associated with maritime climates but can also adapt to semi-arid environments.
